abstract: Stress tests to be released Thursday suggest some banks still need money. But additional funds won’t necessarily come from the government.
snippet: Stress tests to be released Thursday suggest some banks still need money. But additional funds won’t necessarily come from the government.
lead_paragraph: The results of the bank stress tests have been trickling out for days, from Washington and from Wall Street, and the leaks seem to confirm what many bankers feel in their bones: despite all those bailouts, some of the nation’s largest banks still need more money.

headline.main: Banks Need Funds, but Taxpayers May Not Have to Pay
headline.print_headline: Some Big Banks Are Seen in Need Of More Capital

byline.original: By Eric Dash and Louise Story

abstract: Wells Fargo  on Wednesday said it was freezing its cash-balance pension plan for all employees, and has issued layoff notices to 548 workers in uptown Charlotte, N.C., the former home of Wachovia.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo  on Wednesday said it was freezing its cash-balance pension plan for all employees, and has issued layoff notices to 548 workers in uptown Charlotte, N.C., the former home of Wachovia.

headline.main: Wells Fargo Freezes Pension Plan and Cuts 548 Jobs

abstract: Update | 6:28 p.m. Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America disclosed on Thursday afternoon their plans to raise new capital, amid the release of the results of the government-conducted stress tests of banks.
lead_paragraph: Update | 6:28 p.m. Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America disclosed on Thursday afternoon their plans to raise new capital, amid the release of the results of the government-conducted stress tests of banks.

headline.main: Banks Begin Push to Raise More Capital

abstract: After subjecting the biggest U.S. banks to stress tests, regulators ordered 10 to raise more capital and gave the rest clean bills of health.
snippet: After subjecting the biggest U.S. banks to stress tests, regulators ordered 10 to raise more capital and gave the rest clean bills of health.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After subjecting the nation’s biggest banks to the most public scrutiny in decades, federal regulators ordered 10 of them on Thursday to raise a total of $75 billion in extra capital and gave the rest a clean bill of health.

headline.main: Ailing Banks Need $75 Billion, U.S. Says
headline.print_headline: BANKS TOLD THEY NEED $75 BILLION IN EXTRA CAPITAL

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Bank of New York Mellon Corp

abstract: The results gave a broad sense of the banking industry’s troubles and drew a line between strong and weak banks.
snippet: The results gave a broad sense of the banking industry’s troubles and drew a line between strong and weak banks.
lead_paragraph: At one bank in Alabama, the problem is a construction bust. At two in Ohio, the trouble is real estate. And in San Francisco, at Wells Fargo, the worry is credit cards — a staggering 26 percent of that bank’s card loans, federal regulators have concluded, might go bad if the economy takes a turn for the worse.

headline.main: Stress Test Results Split Financial Landscape

byline.original: By Louise Story and Eric Dash
